medipy.base¶

class medipy.base.Command(label='')¶

Abstract base class for all commands.

execute()¶

Execute the command. This function must be reimplemented in derived classes.

class medipy.base.UndoableCommand(label='')¶

Abstract base class for all undo-able commands.

undo()¶

Execute the command. This function must be reimplemented in derived classes.

exception medipy.base.Exception(*args, **kwargs)¶

Base class for all exceptions in MediPy.

medipy.base.find_resource(where)¶

Return the absolute file name of a resource inside the project. This function is necessary as bbfreeze cannot embed arbitrary files.

class medipy.base.History(maximum_steps=None)¶

History of Commands with multiple undo/redo levels.

add(command)¶

Execute the command, and add it to the history.

can_redo¶

Test if an redo operation can be performed.

can_undo¶

Test if an undo operation can be performed.

cursor¶

Current position in the history. Latest commands have lower indices than earliest commands : the earlist command has index steps_count, the latest has index 0.

empty¶

Test if the history is empty.

labels¶

Return a list of commands labels, ordered from latest to earliest.

redo(count=1)¶

Redo the current command.

steps_count¶

Number of steps in the history.

undo(count=1)¶

Undo the current command.

class medipy.base.Image(shape=(0, ), dtype=<type 'numpy.float32'>, spacing=None, origin=None, direction=None, data_type='scalar', image_type='normal', annotations=None, metadata=None, **kwargs)¶
n-dimensional image class, based on numpy.ndarray. An image contains
  • an array of voxel data (image.data), which can also be directly accessed : image.data[something] can be written as image[something]
  • a transformation to convert the voxel space to and from the physical space (origin, direction, spacing). A voxel index I is converted to a physical point P by : P = direction * spacing * I + origin. If not specified, origin is 0, spacing is 1 and direction is identity.
  • a dictionary of metadata
The data has two kinds of interpretation :
  • data_type : whether the data is scalar, vector or matrix
  • image_type : how the image should be interpreted, can be unspecified
(normal), “rgb”, “tensor_2”, or spectroscopy

If data_type == “vector” or data_type == “matrix”, an array of dimension N will have a spacing of size N-1 (resp. N-2)

>>> image1 = Image((40, 128, 128, 6), data_type="scalar")
>>> image2 = Image((40, 128, 128, 6), data_type="vector")
>>> print image1.spacing, image2.spacing
[ 1.  1.  1.  1.] [ 1.  1.  1.]

DTI images can be conveniently created using the dti argument, resulting in a vector image with the correct number of components : >>> image = Image((40, 128, 128), dti=”tensor_2”) >>> print image.shape, image.data_type, image.spacing (40, 128, 128, 6) vector [ 1. 1. 1.]

The following events may be fired :
  • modified
astype(dtype)¶

Copy of the image, cast to a specified type.

computed_ndim¶

Return the dimensionality of the image, neglecting the first values that are equal to 1. An image with a shape of (1,1,256,256,128) will have a ndim of 5 and a computed_ndim of 3. For this image, the computed_ndim only considers (256,256,128).

copy_information(source)¶

Copy information from source image to self

direction¶

Direction cosine matrix.

dtype¶

dtype of the underlying array.

index_to_physical(index)¶

Transform an index coordinate to a physical coordinate.

is_inside(position)¶

Test if given position is inside the image

modified()¶

Send a modified event to the observers

ndim¶

Number of dimensions in the image. This property accounts for non-scalar data, i.e.

>>> image = medipy.base.Image(shape=(256, 256, 256, 3), data_type="scalar", image_type="rgb")
>>> image.ndim
3
number_of_components¶

Return the number of scalar components per voxel.

origin¶

Physical coordinates in millimeters of the voxel with index coordinates (0,0,0).

physical_to_index(physical)¶

Transform a physical coordinate to an index coordinate.

shape¶

Shape of the image. This property accounts for non-scalar data, i.e.

>>> image = medipy.base.Image(shape=(256, 256, 256, 3), data_type="scalar", image_type="rgb")
>>> image.shape
(256, 256, 256)
spacing¶

Image spacing in millimeters.

class medipy.base.ImageAnnotation(position=None, label=None, shape=None, size=None, color=None, filled=None, comment=None)¶

Annotation localized on an image. Position is in mm, expressed as (z,y,x). Can fire the following events :

  • position : old_value
  • label : old_value
  • shape : old_value
  • size : old_value
  • color : old_value
  • filled : old_value
  • comment : old_value
class Shape¶

Image shape.

cross = 2¶
cube = 1¶
point = 3¶
sphere = 0¶
static to_name(value)¶

Convert a shape value to its name.

>>> medipy.base.ImageAnnotation.Shape.to_name(0)
"sphere"
medipy.base.LateBindingProperty¶

Late-binding property, allow easier usage of properties with derived classes.

Regular properties require to redefine the property in derived classes, while LateBindingProperty does not :

>>> class C(object):
... 
...     def getx(self):
...         print 'C.getx'
...         return self._x
... 
...     def setx(self, x):
...         print 'C.setx'
...         self._x = x
... 
...     x = LateBindingProperty(getx, setx)
>>> class D(C):
... 
...     def setx(self, x):
...         print 'D.setx'
...         super(D, self).setx(x)
>>> c = C()
>>> c.x = 1
C.setx
>>> c.x
C.getx
1
>>> d = D()
>>> d.x = 1
D.setx
C.setx
>>> d.x
C.getx
1

Source : http://code.activestate.com/recipes/408713/#c1

class medipy.base.Observable(allowed_events=None)¶

Base class for observable classes. This class defines a simple interface to add or remove observers on an object

add_allowed_event(event)¶

Add an allowed event. Return False if the event was already allowed, else return True.

add_observer(event, observer)¶

Add an observer to the object. Return False if the observer was already in the list, otherwise return True

allowed_events¶

Events allowed for the current object.

has_observer(event, observer)¶

Test if the object has a specific observer

is_allowed_event(event)¶

Test if event is allowed for the current object.

notify_observers(event, *args, **kwargs)¶

Notify observers of a given event. The event must be a member function of the observer. Arguments will depend on the event. Events are documented in the concrete observable classes

remove_observer(event, observer)¶

Remove an observer from the object. Return False if the observer was not in the list. Otherwise return True
